3.1 Skill Categories

Building awareness around the potential negative consequences of encountering high-risk situations and thoughts that associate substance use with good outcomes (i.e., it challenges positive expectancies surrounding substance use
Helping the patient to develop and expand their repertoire of coping skills that address specific high-risk situations for relapse (often called â€œtriggersâ€), whether those situations lead to drug use-related thoughts, feelings, or bodily sensations

Skills range from techniques to communicate with others when in a risky situation (e.g., how to confidently and comfortably say â€œnoâ€ to a drink if it is offered, called â€œassertive drink and drug refusalâ€), to â€œurge surfing,â€ a technique to help individuals cope with the intense longings to consume the substance that occurs during cravings

Planning for â€œemergencies.â€ That is, unexpected situations where the patient finds themselves suddenly struggling to abstain from drinking or using other drugs
Assessing and reinforcing the patientâ€™s confidence in his/her ability to abstain from substance use, even in the face of challenging situations (e.g., self-efficacy)
Finding alternative ways of thinking about positive thoughts related to substance use, and negative thoughts related to abstinence, sometimes called â€œcognitive restructuring.â€ This activity includes discussing the thinking â€œtrapsâ€ (sometimes called cognitive distortions, or unhelpful thinking styles) that can develop after years of drinking and using other drugs. 3 ğŸ“ Spending Time in Risky Situations

3.0.1 Spending Time in Risky Places: What It Means for Recovery
If youâ€™ve recently spent time in a place that felt risky for your recoveryâ€”like a bar, a party, a certain neighborhood, or even someoneâ€™s houseâ€”youâ€™re not alone. Recovery doesnâ€™t happen in a bubble. Sometimes you end up in places that remind you of drinking or make it harder to stay sober.
The good news is: just because you were in a risky place doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™ve failed. What matters most is what you learn from the experience and what you do next.


3.0.2 What Makes a Place Risky?
A risky location is any place that makes it more likely for you to drink or think about drinking. These might include:

Bars or liquor stores
Parties or events where people are drinking
Homes or hangouts where you used to drink
Workplaces or social events that feel stressful
Places tied to strong memories of alcohol use

Whatâ€™s risky for one person might not be risky for another. What matters is how you feel when youâ€™re there.


3.0.3 Why Does It Matter?
Being in risky places can:

Trigger cravings or urges to drink
Bring back old memories or habits
Make you feel out of place or left out
Lower your guard when it comes to saying â€œnoâ€

Even if you donâ€™t drink, just being in a risky spot can make staying sober harder. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important to check in with yourself after being in one.


3.0.4 Why Do People End Up in Risky Places?
There are lots of reasons why you might go to a risky place:

You didnâ€™t realize it would feel triggering
You didnâ€™t want to miss out or disappoint others
You thought you could handle it
You were caught off guard or didnâ€™t plan ahead
You were feeling lonely, bored, or stressed

Againâ€”this happens. The important part is recognizing it and taking steps to protect your recovery going forward.


3.0.5 You Can Learn from the Experience
Spending time in a risky place doesnâ€™t undo your recovery. Itâ€™s a chance to learn more about your triggers and prepare better for the future.
Ask yourself:

What made this place feel risky for me?
How did I feel while I was there?
What might I do differently next time?

Being honest about your experience helps you grow stronger and stay in control of your recovery.


3.0.6 Youâ€™re Still in Charge
Just because you were in a risky place doesnâ€™t mean you have to stay thereâ€”or go back. Youâ€™re in control of your choices. You can:

Decide not to return to that place
Make a plan to bring support with you next time
Set boundaries for where you go and for how long
Focus on people and places that support your recovery

Recovery is about making decisions that protect your well-beingâ€”one step, one choice at a time.


3.0.7 Moving Forward from Here
The following tools and exercises can help you:

Reflect on what made the location feel risky
Strengthen your boundaries
Build a plan for how to handle similar situations in the future
Remind yourself why youâ€™re committed to staying sober

Being in a risky place doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™ve failedâ€”itâ€™s a sign youâ€™re learning, growing, and doing the hard work of recovery. Youâ€™ve got this.

title: 5Â  past_use_psychoed
text:
6 âš ï¸ Alcohol Use During Recovery

6.0.1 Understanding a Slip or Recent Alcohol Use
If youâ€™ve recently had a drink or slipped in your recovery, you might be feeling a mix of emotionsâ€”guilt, frustration, sadness, or even fear. First, take a deep breath.
A slip does not mean youâ€™ve failed. Itâ€™s a sign that recovery is still in progressâ€”and thatâ€™s okay.


6.0.2 Slips Happen in Recovery
A slip is when someone who is trying to stop drinking has a drink after a period of being sober. It can be one drink, or it can last longer. A slip does not mean you canâ€™t stay soberâ€”it means thereâ€™s more to learn about what makes you want to drink and how to handle those moments. Slips are a COMMON, NORMAL part of recovery and can actually serve as powerful learning moments if you explore them without judgment


6.0.3 Why Do Slips Happen?
Slips can happen for many reasons, such as:

Stress: When life feels overwhelming or too hard
Strong cravings: When urges to drink feel too powerful to ignore
Emotions: Feeling lonely, sad, angry, or even too happy
Triggers: Being in a place, around certain people, or in a situation where you used to drink
Low confidence: Thinking â€œI canâ€™t do this,â€ or â€œItâ€™s just one drink, it wonâ€™t matterâ€

Knowing what led to the slip can help you avoid it in the future.


6.0.4 What Can You Do After a Slip?
What you do after a slip is what really matters. You donâ€™t have to wait until next week, next month, or after â€œone last drinkâ€ to get back on track. You can restart right now. Some helpful actions after slips are:

Be honest with yourself â€“ Donâ€™t pretend it didnâ€™t happen. Admitting it helps you move forward.
Let go of shame â€“ You made a mistake, but youâ€™re not a failure. Everyone makes mistakes.
Figure out what led to the slip â€“ Think about the situation, thoughts, or feelings that came before it.
Make a plan for next time â€“ Decide what youâ€™ll do differently if a similar situation comes up again.
Reach out â€“ Talk to someone who supports your recovery. You donâ€™t have to go through this alone.



6.0.5 What You Tell Yourself Matters
After a slip, itâ€™s easy to think:

â€œI blew it.â€
â€œI have to start all over.â€
â€œIâ€™ll never be able to stay sober.â€

But these thoughts are not trueâ€”and theyâ€™re not helpful. Instead, try thinking:

â€œI had a setback, but Iâ€™m still moving forward.â€
â€œI can learn from this.â€
â€œIâ€™m still in recovery, and Iâ€™m not giving up.â€



6.0.6 A Slip Doesnâ€™t Erase Your Progress
All the work youâ€™ve done so far still counts. One slip doesnâ€™t erase your growth, your effort, or your reasons for wanting to stay sober. Youâ€™ve already taken steps toward changeâ€”and those steps still matter.
Recovery isnâ€™t about being perfect. Itâ€™s about getting back up when things get hard. Every time you do that, you build strength.


6.0.7 You Can Start Againâ€”Right Now
You donâ€™t have to wait for a perfect moment. You can restart right now, in this moment. Take a deep breath, and take the next small step.
The tools and exercises that follow are here to help you:

Understand what happened
Reconnect to your recovery goals
Strengthen your plan for staying sober

Youâ€™re not starting over. Youâ€™re continuing your journeyâ€”stronger, wiser, and more prepared than before.

title: 7Â  Craving psychoeducation
text:
8 ğŸŒŠ Understanding Cravings
As you work on changing your drinking, itâ€™s normal to have urges or cravings for alcohol. A craving is when you feel the strong urge to drink, even though you donâ€™t want to. This can show up as thoughts, emotions, or physical sensations that pull you toward drinking, even if part of you wants to stay sober.
Good news: Cravings are short-lived, predictable, and controllable. With practice, they will get weaker, and youâ€™ll feel more confident in handling them when they pop up.

8.0.1 What is a Craving?
A craving is a powerful feeling that pushes you to drink alcohol, even when you donâ€™t want to. It can feel like a strong mental or physical need to drink. Cravings happen because of the long-term use of alcohol, and they can last for some time after you stop drinking.
If youâ€™ve had a lot of drinking in the past, cravings may come up more often or feel stronger. But donâ€™t worry! Cravings are a normal part of recovery, and they happen at all stages of recovery.


8.0.2 How Do Cravings Show Up?
Cravings can look different for everyone. Here are some ways cravings might show up for you:

Physical feelings: You might feel shaky, sweaty, or have a racing heart.
Thoughts: You might think, â€œI want a drink,â€ or â€œIt would be fun to drink with my friends right now.â€
Emotions: Cravings can come with feelings like anxiety, frustration, or sadness.
Behaviors: You might find yourself lingering near places where alcohol is sold, or spending time with others who are drinking.



8.0.3 Cravings Are Predictable
Cravings donâ€™t happen randomly. They can be triggered by certain situations or emotions. These triggers can be internal (how youâ€™re feeling) or external (things around you).

Internal triggers: These are feelings or thoughts that can bring on cravings, like stress, sadness, or even excitement. You might also feel physical discomfort, like being tired or in pain.
External triggers: These are things in the environment that remind you of drinking, like seeing alcohol, being around people who drink, or even times of day when you used to drink.

The more you recognize what causes your cravings, the better you can plan for them. Understanding what triggers your cravings can help you avoid or manage them.


8.0.4 Cravings Are Temporary
Cravings might feel intense, but hereâ€™s the important thing to remember: they donâ€™t last long. Most cravings only last a few minutes. Think of a craving like a wave in the ocean. It starts small, gets bigger, and then crashes and disappears.
Even though cravings can feel overwhelming at first, they are time-limited and will pass. The key is not giving in to the craving. The more you ignore the craving and choose not to drink, the weaker it becomes.


8.0.5 Cravings Get Easier Over Time
At the start of your recovery, cravings may be stronger and more frequent. But over time, they will get weaker and less intense. Each time you resist the urge to drink, the craving loses power.
Stopping alcohol use completely is the fastest way to get rid of cravings. If you donâ€™t reward craving with alcohol use, it will eventually go away. Itâ€™s like feeding a stray animal. If you stop feeding it, it will stop coming back.


8.0.6 What Can You Do When a Craving Hits?
When you feel a craving, remember: itâ€™s temporary and you can control how you respond. Here are some ways to deal with cravings:

Pause and Breathe: Take a deep breath. Focus on the present moment.
Distraction: Do something else to take your mind off the craving, like going for a walk, calling a friend, or reading a book.
Urge Surfing: Imagine the craving is like a waveâ€”let it build, but know it will crash and pass.
Reach Out: Talk to someone you trust, like a sponsor or a friend. Sometimes, just sharing how you feel can help.




8.0.7 Remember: Cravings Donâ€™t Last Forever
Itâ€™s completely normal to experience cravings in recovery. But the more you practice coping with them, the easier it will get. Cravings are like visitorsâ€”they come and go. With time and practice, you will get better at handling them.
By staying sober, even when cravings are strong, youâ€™ll find that the cravings become less powerful and easier to ignore. Youâ€™ve got this!

10 ğŸ’ª Understanding Motivation in Recovery
When you are in recovery, there will be times when you feel less motivated or less confident about staying sober. This can happen for many reasons, and itâ€™s important to know that itâ€™s normal to feel this way sometimes.
Low motivation means you might not feel like putting in the effort to stay sober. Low confidence means you might not believe that you have the ability to stay sober, even if you want to.
The good news is that both motivation and confidence to keep abstinent can be worked on and improved during recovery. By practicing some simple strategies, you can boost your confidence in your ability to stay sober and get back on track with your recovery.
1. What is Motivation, Really?

Motivation isnâ€™t all or nothing â€” itâ€™s fluid.
It often changes day-to-day or even moment-to-moment.
Feeling unsure or unmotivated doesnâ€™t mean failure â€” itâ€™s actually a normal part of the change process.

â€œYou donâ€™t need to be 100% motivated to start moving in the right direction.â€
2. Why Does Motivation Drop?

You might feel burned out, discouraged, or just disconnected from why you started.
Cravings, stress, or life stuff can make alcohol seem like a quick fix again.
Sometimes itâ€™s hard to imagine life without drinking â€” especially if itâ€™s been a big part of coping, social life, or routine.
If you donâ€™t see quick results or progress in your recovery, it can sometimes make you feel like itâ€™s not working, lowering your motivation
When we are doing well in our recovery, sometimes our mind tries to trick us into thinking that we can handle a drink or two now. This slippery slope is called â€œAbstinence driftâ€

3. What Actually Helps Motivation?
Motivation grows when we:

Understand our own reasons for change (not just what others want for us).
Explore what matters to us â€” like health, family, freedom, or peace of mind.
Feel heard, not judged â€” and have support that fits us, not a one-size-fits-all model.

4. The Change Process Has Stages
You donâ€™t have to be â€œready to quit foreverâ€ to start growing. Most people move through these stages:

Not yet thinking about change (Precontemplation)
Thinking about it (Contemplation)
Preparing to try (Preparation)
Taking action (Action)
Working to maintain it (Maintenance)

Interventions are meant to meet you where you are â€” not push you where youâ€™re not ready to go.
5. How to increase motivation and confidence

Set Small, Achievable Goals: Instead of focusing on big, overwhelming goals, set smaller, more manageable goals. For example, focus on staying sober for today, or for the next hour.



Celebrate Your Successes: Each time you meet a small goal, celebrate it! Recognizing your successes, even the small ones, will boost your motivation and remind you that you can do this.



Remind Yourself of Your Reasons: Keep a list of why you want to stay sober. When motivation is low, read through this list to remind yourself why recovery is important to you.



Visualize Your Success: Imagine yourself succeeding in your recovery. Picture yourself feeling strong, confident, and sober. This positive mental image can help build your belief in yourself.



Use Support Networks: Talk to people who support your recovery. Hearing encouraging words from a friend, sponsor, or counselor can help lift your spirits and boost your motivation.



Practice Self-Compassion: If you make a mistake or slip, donâ€™t be hard on yourself. Be kind and remind yourself that setbacks happen. What matters is getting back on track.

6. Bottom Line

Itâ€™s okay to feel unsure. Thatâ€™s a signal to get curious, not give up.
Motivation can be built, just like a muscle.
The goal is progress, not perfection â€” and you donâ€™t have to do it alone.

12.0.1 Spending Time in Risky Places: What It Means for Recovery
If youâ€™ve recently spent time in a place that felt risky for your recoveryâ€”like a bar, a party, a certain neighborhood, or even someoneâ€™s houseâ€”youâ€™re not alone. Recovery doesnâ€™t happen in a bubble. Sometimes you end up in places that remind you of drinking or make it harder to stay sober.
The good news is: just because you were in a risky place doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™ve failed. What matters most is what you learn from the experience and what you do next.


12.0.2 What Makes a Place Risky?
A risky location is any place that makes it more likely for you to drink or think about drinking. These might include:

Bars or liquor stores
Parties or events where people are drinking
Homes or hangouts where you used to drink
Workplaces or social events that feel stressful
Places tied to strong memories of alcohol use

Whatâ€™s risky for one person might not be risky for another. What matters is how you feel when youâ€™re there.


12.0.3 Why Does It Matter?
Being in risky places can:

Trigger cravings or urges to drink
Bring back old memories or habits
Make you feel out of place or left out
Lower your guard when it comes to saying â€œnoâ€

Even if you donâ€™t drink, just being in a risky spot can make staying sober harder. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important to check in with yourself after being in one.


12.0.4 Why Do People End Up in Risky Places?
There are lots of reasons why you might go to a risky place:

You didnâ€™t realize it would feel triggering
You didnâ€™t want to miss out or disappoint others
You thought you could handle it
You were caught off guard or didnâ€™t plan ahead
You were feeling lonely, bored, or stressed

Againâ€”this happens. The important part is recognizing it and taking steps to protect your recovery going forward.


12.0.5 You Can Learn from the Experience
Spending time in a risky place doesnâ€™t undo your recovery. Itâ€™s a chance to learn more about your triggers and prepare better for the future.
Ask yourself:

What made this place feel risky for me?
How did I feel while I was there?
What might I do differently next time?

Being honest about your experience helps you grow stronger and stay in control of your recovery.


12.0.6 Youâ€™re Still in Charge
Just because you were in a risky place doesnâ€™t mean you have to stay thereâ€”or go back. Youâ€™re in control of your choices. You can:

Decide not to return to that place
Make a plan to bring support with you next time
Set boundaries for where you go and for how long
Focus on people and places that support your recovery

Recovery is about making decisions that protect your well-beingâ€”one step, one choice at a time.


12.0.7 Moving Forward from Here
The following tools and exercises can help you:

Reflect on what made the location feel risky
Strengthen your boundaries
Build a plan for how to handle similar situations in the future
Remind yourself why youâ€™re committed to staying sober

Being in a risky place doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™ve failedâ€”itâ€™s a sign youâ€™re learning, growing, and doing the hard work of recovery. Youâ€™ve got this.
